summary: This document is an email chain between prosecutors and defense attorneys in the Ghislaine Maxwell case regarding discovery issues. It discusses technical problems with providing discovery materials to Maxwell in prison, metadata issues with files from Epstein's devices, and the production of materials including nude and non-nude images seized from Epstein's residences.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C. representing Ghislaine Maxwell. She is corresponding with prosecutors about discovery issues, specifically requesting metadata and file format information for materials from Epstein's devices.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Attorney at Cohen & Gresser LLP representing Ghislaine Maxwell. He initiates the email chain raising multiple discovery issues regarding file access, metadata, and missing attachments.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Defense attorney cc'd on the correspondence regarding discovery issues in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: Defense attorney cc'd on the correspondence regarding discovery issues in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the case. The correspondence discusses difficulties in providing her with discovery materials while she is incarcerated at MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center).

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge mentioned in the context of potentially needing a court order to facilitate delivery of discovery materials to Maxwell at MDC.

connections.description: Menninger is a defense attorney representing Maxwell in the criminal case, as evidenced by her correspondence about discovery issues on Maxwell's behalf.
Everdell is a defense attorney representing Maxwell, initiating discovery requests and discussing access to materials for his client.
Pagliuca is cc'd on defense correspondence regarding Maxwell's case, indicating involvement in her legal defense.
Sternheim is cc'd on defense correspondence regarding Maxwell's case, indicating involvement in her legal defense.
Both are defense attorneys working together on Ghislaine Maxwell's case, coordinating on discovery issues.
The document references materials seized from Epstein's devices and residences that are part of the discovery in Maxwell's case, indicating their connection.

events.title: Searches of Epstein residences
events.description: FBI searches of Jeffrey Epstein's residences mentioned as the source of CDs containing images that were later produced in discovery.

events.title: November 9, 2020 discovery production
events.description: Prosecution produced discovery materials including images from CDs seized during 2019 searches of Epstein residences.

events.title: October 20, 2020 production
events.description: Prosecution produced videos converted from VHS and cassette tapes from SDFL or PBPD investigations.

events.title: Discovery issues raised
events.description: Defense attorneys raise multiple technical issues with discovery materials, including file access problems for Maxwell at MDC and metadata concerns.

events.title: Supplementary discovery production
events.description: Prosecution provides additional discovery materials to defense counsel, including a cover letter and spreadsheet related to SUPP production.

keyFacts: Defense attorneys raised significant technical issues with discovery materials, including over 109,000 emails produced without attachments and over 110,000 electronic documents with metadata issues from Epstein's devices.
Prosecution acknowledged that files carved or deleted from Epstein's devices had no recoverable metadata, limiting what could be provided to the defense.
Images within Bates range SDNY_GM_00467566 through SDNY_GM_00514100 were seized during 2019 searches of Epstein residences and included both nude and non-nude images.
The defense reported that Ghislaine Maxwell could not read some discovery files on prison computers and requested alternative methods of delivery.
Prosecution indicated they were not permitted to send drives to MDC that their IT department did not load, creating logistical challenges for providing discovery to the incarcerated defendant.
